I invented this dragon-warrior some time ago, when i was in search of additional sources of AC for a STR-based character that can take upon some extreme challenges presented in WoG, such as face-tanking the "White Dragon King" and similar things. That is, i wanted a straight-up beater, no temporal buffs of any kind that would be lost from a well placed Dispel/ Mord's or anything else. It seems that the only extra sources of this kind would come from a pale master and nothing else, but these characters have their own agenda, so i was left with a choice that i would not normally take under normal circumstances. And so i took upon the chalenge and worked full time on that, making what you are gonna see below and i was quite satisfied so to say, from the final results. This character has a constant 70 AC in WoG (and WoG is on the low side of madium -magic PW's), that rises to 80 AC when he makes use of his improved expertise fighting mode. I made a point also to have the earliest possible full-blown RDD for extreme playability, it is basically a lvl 20 builded RDD in a lvl 40 build for that purpose.

Possibly the only build that compares with this one, is the "Avatar of the forge" by grizzled_dwarflord, they have a similar concept, mine is quite a bit more tanky so to say, while his build has some buff potencial and a slightly better song because he takes 12 lvls of Bard.

Avatar of the forge --> http://home.comcast.net/~worldofgreyhaw ... 00533.html

The opposite of this build (Bard 20/ Rdd 10/ Ftr 10), works really well too and maybe it is slightly better overall but it looses quite a bit on the hp's department and has no DR to speak off and anyway it is a build already well-known by now, but i will leave that kind of build for a future concept and move on to what we have now at our hands.

-- Draco Mauler has the earliest possible full RDD development from all dragon builds.
-- Draco Mauler has the best tanking abilities amongst all of his breathren, including concentration skill and a dragonic armour that has almost double the thickness.
-- Draco Mauler has an incredible amount of hp's & a moderate amount of DR, backed up with solid saves and that is especially true when it comes against spellcasters.
-- Draco Mauler hits incredibly hard with his all-natural 40 STR further utilising advanced Fighter techniques (EWS) and Arcane knowledge (UMD).

And that's it, a straight-up scrapper that will never let you down and is playable from the start-up, enjoy!

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Thanks, Kal, I know its tough to leave it at EDR II, it annoys me as well, but if I dropped AS for it, then all the trouble that I went for getting 39AC mundane would drop to almost the "default" levels of RDD (36). Taunt is nice to have, I agree, but without a Charisma bonus or ESF: Taunt, it is not likely to work where you need it to. Tell you what, if you're willing to compromise with "only" 44AB & 44(50) Dev Crit DC, then I would change two Great Strengths for both EDR III & ESF: Taunt.

One might question my "dedication " to AC, for this particular build, but they have to remember that the higher one gets in the AC scale, the bigger the impact of each AC increase that you get. For example, if your standard warrior is getting hit 45% of the time & your "normal" Ftr/Bard/Rdd is getting hit 25% of the time, then this THICK Rdd, narrows that to only 10%. That's near invulnerability!

Now I have to ask: how have you calculated the percentage of being hit?
From personal experience & basic principals of world-building.
You want your monsters to hit good warrior-types about 50% of the time (assuming full tumble & plate & shield) for level appropriate areas.
So, if 50% is the norm, then Rdd with the same stuff will be hit about 30% of the time (+4AC over the standard warrior) & this guy gets hit about 15% of the time (+3AC over standard Rdd).
And from my experience, this is about right, in fact, prepared warriors take even less hits because they also use personal buffs (like imp. invisibility).
